CARDINAL . The facts concerning the background of application no . CARDINAL , including the NORP armed conflict of DATE and the period up to DATE , are set out in GPE , ORG and PERSON v. GPE and GPE [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL , ECHR CARDINALVII .
CARDINAL . The first and second applicants were detained until their release , respectively on CARDINAL and DATE , in the “ GPE ( FAC ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first and second applicants were tried and convicted by ORG for various crimes and offences such as murder , deliberate destruction of another ’s property and the unauthorised use and theft of ammunition or explosive substances . They were sentenced to DATE imprisonment and confiscation of their property .

CARDINAL . In DATE the first and second applicants , as well as CARDINAL other individuals who had been tried and convicted with them in DATE , namely PERSON and Mr PERSON , filed an application with the ORG concerning , inter alia , the alleged unlawfulness of their detention and their conditions of detention .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE in application no . CARDINAL the Grand Chamber of the ORG found that both GPE and GPE responsibility was engaged with regard to the acts complained of and held that there had been violations of various Articles of the Convention ( see below , paragraph CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . In the first place , the ORG found that ORG was the only legitimate government of GPE under international law , but that it did not exercise authority over that part of its territory that was under the effective control of the “ GPE ( FAC ) . Nevertheless , in the ORG ’s opinion , ORG were under a positive obligation under LAW to take the diplomatic , economic , judicial or other measures that were in their power to take and that were in accordance with international law to secure to the applicants the rights guaranteed by ORG , ORG and PERSON v. GPE and GPE ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL-VII , § § CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) .

It further stated that it was not its task to indicate which measures the authorities had to take in order to comply with their obligations most effectively , but that it had to verify that the measures actually taken were appropriate and sufficient in the present case . When faced with a partial or total failure to act , the ORG ’s task was to determine to what extent a minimum effort was nevertheless possible and whether it should have been made . Determining that question was especially necessary in cases concerning an alleged infringement of absolute rights such as those guaranteed by ORG and CARDINAL of the Convention ( ibid . § CARDINAL ) .

The ORG noted that until DATE , the GPE authorities had taken various measures aimed at obtaining the applicants’ release and that as a result , Mr PERSON was released in DATE . It considered that even after Mr PERSON ’s release in DATE , it was within the power of ORG to take measures to secure to the applicants their rights under LAW . It further noted that the negotiations for a settlement of the situation in GPE , in which GPE was acting as a guarantor ORG , had been on - going since DATE without any mention of the applicants or without any measure being taken or considered by the GPE authorities to secure the applicants their Convention rights , although it was within the power of ORG to take such measures ( ibid . , § PERSON CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

The ORG therefore held that GPE ’s responsibility was capable of being engaged under the Convention on account of its failure to discharge its positive obligations with regard to the acts complained of which occurred after DATE ( ibid . , § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . As to GPE , the ORG found that all of the acts committed by the NORP soldiers with regard to the applicants before the ratification of the LAW by GPE , including their transfer into the charge of the NORP separatist regime , in the context of the NORP authorities’ collaboration with that illegal regime , were capable of engaging responsibility for the acts of that regime ( ibid . , § CARDINAL ) .

Turning to the question whether that responsibility was still engaged at the time of the ratification of the Convention by GPE , the ORG found that the “ FAC , which had been set up in DATE with the support of GPE and was vested with organs of power and its own administration , remained “ under the effective authority , or at the very least under the decisive influence of GPE , and in any event , it survives by virtue of the military , economic , financial and political support given to it by the GPE ” ( ibid . , § CARDINAL ) .

It therefore held that there was a continuous and uninterrupted link of responsibility on the part of GPE for the applicants’ fate , as GPE policy of support for the regime and collaboration with it continued beyond CARDINAL DATE , the date of entry into force of the LAW in respect of GPE , and after that date GPE had made no attempt to put an end to the applicants’ situation brought about by its agents , and did not act to prevent the violations allegedly committed after DATE . In the light of these findings , it considered it to be of little consequence that since CARDINAL DATE the agents of GPE have not participated directly in the events complained of in that application ( ibid . , § MONEY ) .
The ORG held that the applicants came within the “ jurisdiction ” of GPE for the purposes of LAW and its responsibility was engaged with regard to the acts complained of ( ibid . , § CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Applying these findings ( paragraphs CARDINAL above ) to the alleged substantive violations of the LAW , the ORG further found , in respect of the applicants PERSON and PERSON :

i ) that their detention was contrary to LAW , that , since the applicants were still detained , this violation was of a continuous nature ( § MONEY ) , and that the conduct constituting a violation of this provision was imputable both to GPE as from DATE , and to GPE as from DATE ( § CARDINAL ) ;

ii ) that any continuation of the unlawful and arbitrary detention of the applicants would necessarily entail a serious prolongation of the violation of LAW respondent States’ obligation under LAW to abide by the ORG ’s judgment , and indicated that “ the respondent GPE must take every measure to put an end to the arbitrary detention of the applicants still detained and to secure their immediate release ” ( § CARDINAL ) ;

iii ) that the persecution , ill - treatment and restrictions to which Mr PERSON was subjected while in detention constituted “ torture ” within the meaning of LAW ( § § CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) , that GPE was responsible for the treatment inflicted on Mr PERSON as from CARDINAL DATE , and that GPE was responsible for that treatment from DATE ( § CARDINAL ) .

iv ) that the harsh conditions of detention experienced by PERSON could be qualified as inhuman and degrading treatment within the meaning of LAW ( § MONEY ) , that GPE was responsible for that violation as from CARDINAL DATE , and that GPE was responsible for that violation as from DATE ( § MONEY ) .

CARDINAL . As to the application of LAW , the ORG ordered GPE and GPE to pay to each applicant the sum of MONEY ( ORG ) for pecuniary and non - pecuniary damages , and awarded the overall sum of LAW for costs and expenses .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG published the report following this visit , which stated , inter alia :

“ CARDINAL . CARDINAL members of the ORG group had been held for DATE under conditions of solitary confinement ( though CARDINAL of them - PERSON - had recently been offered , but had refused , the presence of other prisoners in his cell ) . As regards CARDINAL of the prisoners , there were clear indications that the regime to which he was subject was having harmful psychological consequences . Certain other prisoners interviewed by the delegation had also been held under conditions of solitary confinement for prolonged periods .

The ORG pays particular attention to prisoners held , for whatever reasons , under conditions akin to solitary confinement . The principle of proportionality requires that a balance be struck between the requirements of the case and the application of a solitary - confinement type regime , which is a measure that can have very harmful consequences for the person concerned . Solitary confinement can , in certain circumstances , amount to inhuman and degrading treatment ; in any event , all forms of solitary confinement should be as short as possible . To hold persons under conditions of solitary confinement for DATE on end is scarcely justifiable under any circumstances .

Beyond this , the ORG calls upon the authorities to end the solitary confinement regime applied to PERSON , PERSON and PERSON . Whatever justification there might have been in the past for the application of that regime to these prisoners , to persist with such a regime for DATE is indefensible . ”
